posts.title: Catching Out
posts.excerpt: Quote: The phrase ‘Catching Out’ describes the act of hopping a freight train. In the documentary film “Catching Out,” the adventure begins on the porch of a grainer hurtling through the arid expanse of the Mojave Desert. The journey continues into the unconventional terrain of an American sub-culture. The film features a seasoned eco-activist named …

posts.title: L’amour fou
posts.excerpt: A documentary on the relationship between fashion designer Yves Saint-Laurent and his lover, Pierre Berge.

posts._title: Evald Schorm – Pet holek na krku AKA Saddled with Five Girls (1967)
posts.title: Pet holek na krku
posts.excerpt: From History of Narrative Film by David A. Cook (p712): “Schorm’s third film of contemporary social criticism, Saddled with Five Girls, forms a kind of trilogy with Everyday Courage and The Return of the Prodigal Son. Less pessimistic than his earlier work, Saddled with Five Girls is a film of youthful love and alienation which …

posts.title: Porn Studies
posts.excerpt: In “Hard Core: Power, Pleasure, and the “Frenzy of the Visible”, Linda Williams put moving-image pornography on the map of contemporary scholarship with her path-breaking analysis of the most popular and enduring of all film and video genres. Now, fifteen years later, she showcases the next generation of critical thinking about pornography and signals new …

posts._title: Jan Svankmajer – Zánik domu Usheru AKA Fall of the House of Usher (1982)
posts.title: Zánik domu Usheru
posts.excerpt: In this animated version of Edgar Allan Poe’s story, a traveller arrives at the Usher mansion to find that the sibling inhabitants are living under a mysterious family curse: The brother’s senses have become painfully acute, while his sister has become nearly catatonic. As the visitor’s stay at the mansion continues, the effects of the …

posts._title: Lee De Forest – Casey at the Bat (1922)
posts.title: Casey at the Bat
posts.excerpt: Quote: In his career, De Wolf Hopper recited Ernest Lawrence Thayer’s “Casey at the Bat” thousands of times. Here, wearing a tuxedo, he emerges from behind a curtain as if at a theater, gives a short introduction, and launches into the poem. The camera is stationary, and although Hopper stands in one place, his hands …

posts.title: The Meateater
posts.excerpt: Psycopathic killer stalks teens at a run down, abandoned movie theatre.

posts._title: Jan Svankmajer – Leonarduv denik AKA Leonardo’s Diary (1972)
posts.title: Leonarduv denik
posts.excerpt: Animated drawings inspired by Leonardo da Vinci are intercut with seemingly unrelated (but in fact strangely similar) live-action scenes.

posts._title: Jan Svankmajer – Zvahlav aneb Saticky Slameného Huberta AKA Jabberwocky (1971)
posts.title: Zvahlav aneb Saticky Slameného Huberta
posts.excerpt: Lewis Carroll’s poem is read and followed by a free-form animated depiction of images and toys from childhood, repeatedly overturned by a live cat.
